Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Algebraic Design Theory and Hadamard Matrices, July 8 - 11, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for US researchers who will attend the "Workshop on Algebraic Design Theory and Hadamard Matrices," to be held at University of Lethbridge, Canada, during July 8-11, 2014. The purpose of the workshop is to bring together researchers and students interested in the theory of Hadamard matrices and their applications, as well as related areas such as combinatorial design theory, coding theory, quantum information theory and computer security. The participants will learn about the latest developments in these areas, and explore different visions for setting directions for future work.

Hadamard matrices are indispensable in engineering applications related to mobile communications, data transmission, and error-control codes. In 1893, the great French mathematician Jacques Hadamard posed a problem, which later became known as the Hadamard matrix conjecture, namely, that every positive integer divisible by 4 is the order of a square matrix with entries plus or minus one, and having pairwise orthogonal rows. Although many infinite classes of such matrices are known and a rich theory has evolved, this problem remains unresolved and has risen in the field of combinatorics to a status comparable to that held until recently by Fermat's Last Theorem in number theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop on Algebraic Design Theory and Hadamard Matrices
brought together researchers and students interested in algebraic
design theory, Hadamard matrices and their applications, and
related areas.
Approximately 44 talks in length from 20 to 50 minutes were given
in a lecture room at the University of Lethbridge over a period of 4 days.
Fifty-eight participants from 15 different countries of North America,
Europa, Asia, and Australia had the opportunity to learn about
the latest developments in these areas, discussed the latest findings,
took stock of what remains to be done on classical problems, and
explored avenues for future research.
Karol Zyczkowski, a physicist from Poland with international reputation,
gave a talk on the connection between quantum information and Hadamard matrices.
This talk gave mathematicians useful insights into parallel important research
being done in physics and broke down the barriers between the two fields which
often use divergent notation impeding communication. There were several talks on
mutually unbiased matrices, a topic which is intimately connected with quantum
information theory.
Jonathan Jedwab presented a talk giving several approaches to solve
the famous Zauner's conjecture.
Dokovic and Kotsireas presented a new method for constructing Golay pairs.
The talks by Armario, Seberry, Szollosi discussed the construction of symmetric
conference matrices, and recent progress by Szollosi, Dokovic and Kotsireas to solve
the lowest open order of 66.
Ilya Zhdanovskiy found a new method with algebraic geometry to tackle a
conjecture of Mate Matolcsi regarding complex Hadamard matrices.
It is possible that this approach will lead to the proof of the conjecture,
which, in turn, is likely to play a key role in the solution of the famous
mutually unbiased matrix problem in dimension 6.
Bernhard Schmidt reported recent progress that ruled out around 95% of the
known cases in the Barker sequence conjecture, one of several important conjectures
in the workshop's area.
